xxl.collections
Class AbstractQueue

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--xxl.collections.AbstractQueue
Direct Known Subclasses:
ArrayQueue, FileStackQueue, Heap, ListQueue, StackQueue, StreamQueue
public abstract class AbstractQueue
extends Object
implements Queue

This class provides a skeletal implementation of the Queue interface, to minimize the effort required to implement this interface.

To implement a queue, the programmer needs only to extend this class and provide implementations for the insert, next and size methods.

The documentation for each non-abstract methods in this class describes its implementation in detail. Each of these methods may be overridden if the bag being implemented admits a more efficient implementation.

See Also:
Function, Iterator, Mapper, NoSuchElementException

FACTORY_METHOD

public static final Function FACTORY_METHOD
A factory method to create a default queue (see contract for FACTORY_METHOD in interface Queue). This field is set to Queue.FACTORY_METHOD.
Constructor Detail

AbstractQueue

public AbstractQueue()
Constructs an empty queue.

AbstractQueue

public AbstractQueue(Iterator iterator)
Constructs a queue containing the elements of the specified iterator. This implementation calls insertAll method to insert the elements of the specified iterator.
Parameters:
iterator - the iterator whose elements are to be placed into this queue.

supportsPeek

public boolean supportsPeek()
Returns true if the peek operation is supported by this queue. (In other words, returns true if peek would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)
This implementation always returns false.
Specified by:
supportsPeek in interface Queue
Returns:
true if the peek operation is supported by this queue.

peek

public Object peek()
            throws NoSuchElementException,
                   UnsupportedOperationException
Returns the next element in the queue without removing it. The next element of the queue is given by its strategy.
This implementation always throws an UnsupportedOpertationException.
Specified by:
peek in interface Queue
Returns:
the next element in the queue.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - queue has no more elements.
UnsupportedOperationException - if the peek operation is not supported by this queue.

remove

public void remove()
            throws IllegalStateException,
                   UnsupportedOperationException
Removes from the underlying collection the last element returned by the queue (optional operation). This method can be called only once per call to next or peek. Because of thinkable interactions with other methods (e.g., the hasNext method of a Filter with an underlying iterator removes elements from the iterator) the correct working of a queue can only be guaranteed when remove is immediately called after calls to next or peek. The behavior of a queue is unspecified if the underlying collection is modified while the queue is in progress in any way other than by calling this method.
This implementation always throws an UnsupportedOpertationException.
Specified by:
remove in interface Queue
Returns:
the next element in the queue.
Throws:
IllegalStateException - if the next or peek method has not yet been called, or the remove method has already been called after the last call to the next method.
UnsupportedOperationException - if the remove operation is not supported by this queue.

insertAll

public void insertAll(Iterator objects)
Appends all of the elements in the specified iterator to the end of this queue. The end of the queue is given by its strategy. The behavior of this operation is unspecified if the specified iterator is modified while the operation is in progress.
This implementation iterates over the specified iterator, inserting the elements obtained from it into this queue, in turn.
Specified by:
insertAll in interface Queue
Parameters:
objects - iterator whose elements are to be appended to the end of this queue.

hasNext

public boolean hasNext()
Returns true if the queue has more elements. (In other words, returns true if next would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)
This implementation checks whether the size of this queue is greater than 0. More exactly, it returns (size() > 0).
Specified by:
hasNext in interface Queue
Returns:
true if the queue has more elements.

replace

public Object replace(Object object)
               throws NoSuchElementException
Appends the specified element to the end of this queue and returns the next element in the queue. The end and the next element of the queue are given by its strategy.
Note that using a LIFO strategy forces to store the result of next() before inserting the specified element in order to return the replaced element.
This implementation calls the next method and stores the returned object. Thereafter, it inserts the transmitted object and returns the stored object. Note that this implementation will pass the NoSuchElementException thrown by the next method when the queue has no more elements.
Specified by:
replace in interface Queue
Parameters:
object - element to be appended to the end of this queue.
Returns:
the next element in the queue.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - queue has no more elements.

replaceAll

public Iterator replaceAll(Iterator iterator)
                    throws NoSuchElementException
Appends all of the elements in the specified iterator to the end of this queue and returns an iterator having the same length iterating over the replaced (next) elements of the queue. The end and the next element of the queue are given by its strategy.
All implementations of this method should follow the principle of lazy evaluation i.e. the replacement of an element takes place when calling next() on the returned iterator.
Note that using a LIFO strategy forces to store the result of next() before inserting the specified element in order to return the replaced element.
This implementation returns an iterator wrapping calls to replace(objects.next()) by using a Mapper.
Specified by:
replaceAll in interface Queue
Parameters:
objects - iterator whose elements are to be appended to the end of this queue.
Returns:
an iterator having the same length as objects and iterating over the replaced (next) elements of this queue.
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - queue has no more elements.

clear

public void clear()
Removes all of the elements from this queue. The queue will be empty after this call returns so that size() == 0.
Note that the elements will only be removed from the queue but not from the underlying collection.
This implementation iterates over this queue, calling the next method for every element, in turn. Thereafter, the close method is called.
Specified by:
clear in interface Queue

close

public void close()
Closes this queue and releases any system resources associated with it. This operation is idempotent, i.e., multiple calls of this method takes the same effect as a single call.
Note: This method is very important for queues using external resources like files or JDBC resources.
This implementation is given by an empty body.
Specified by:
close in interface Queue
